sub_topic: Calculating the magnetic moment of inorganic compounds.
message_1: What is the magnetic moment of FeCl3 in a high-spin state with five unpaired electrons?
message_2:
The magnetic moment (µ) of a molecule can be calculated using the formula:

µ = √(n(n+2)) µB

where n is the number of unpaired electrons and µB is the Bohr magneton (approximately 9.274 x 10^-24 J/T).

For FeCl3 in a high-spin state with five unpaired electrons, we can plug the values into the formula:

µ = √(5(5+2)) µB
µ = √(5(7)) µB
µ = √(35) µB

Now, we can multiply by the value of the Bohr magneton:

µ ≈ √(35) x (9.274 x 10^-24 J/T)
µ ≈ 5.92 x (9.274 x 10^-24 J/T)
µ ≈ 5.49 x 10^-23 J/T

So, the magnetic moment of FeCl3 in a high-spin state with five unpaired electrons is approximately 5.49 x 10^-23 J/T.
